awd_abstract_narration: The Learning from Authoritative Security Experiment Results (LASER) workshop series focuses on learning from and improving cyber security experiment results. The workshop explores both positive and negative results, the latter of which are not often published. The workshop strives to provide a highly interactive, collegial environment for discussing and learning from experiment design, issues, and outcomes. Ultimately, it seeks to foster a dramatic change in the paradigm of cyber security research and experimentation, improving the overall quality and reporting of practiced science.

por.por_cntn:
The Learning from Authoritative Security Experiment Results (LASER) workshop series focuses on learning from and improving cybersecurity experiment results. The workshop strives to provide a highly interactive, collegial environment for discussing and learning from experimental methodologies, execution, and results. Ultimately, the workshop seeks to foster a dramatic change in the experimental paradigm for cybersecurity research, improving the overall quality and reporting of practiced science. More information about the LASER workshop can be found at https://laser-workshop.org/.

LASER is run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), a non-profit association of computer security professionals with a common goal of improving the understanding, theory, and practice of computer security. To this end, ACSA supports a number of activities, all of which serve the goal of improving the computer security field. See https://www.appliedcomputersecurity.org/ for more information about ACSA.

The NSF Support for LASER Workshop Series grant was intended to support two workshops and ended up supporting three workshops, in 2016, 2017, and 2020. The workshop programs were comprised of one or two days of invited talks, panel sessions, and technical paper presentations, focused on experimental aspects of cybersecurity research. The workshops attracted a combination of participants from industry, government, and academia (faculty and students).

The 2016 workshop was held as an IEEE Security & Privacy Workshops (SPW) collocated with the IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (IEEE S&P) in San Jose, CA on May 26, 2016, and featured an invited talk, panel discussion, and six paper presentations (accepted from among 12 submissions). The 2017 workshop was held as a standalone workshop at SRI International’s conference facility in Arlington, VA on October 18-19, 2017, and featured two invited talks, a panel discussion, and eight paper presentations (accepted from among 15 submissions). The 2020 workshop was collocated with the Internet Society Network and Distributed System Security (NDSS) Symposium in San Diego, CA on February 23, 2020, and featured one invited talk and seven invited presentations. The attached table provides additional information on the LASER 2016, 2017, and 2020 workshops.

One of the goals of the LASER Workshop Series grant was to provide opportunities for student education and some of the NSF funds supported student participation in the workshops. Students gained valuable insight into the experimental aspects of cybersecurity research. A number of students shared their research with other workshop participants by presenting papers. The invited talks and panels gave students further insights into focused issues and challenges regarding cybersecurity experimentation.

The LASER workshop is widely publicized and open to all members of the cybersecurity experimental research community. The 2016 and 2017 workshop proceedings were published via open access by USENIX. The 2020 workshop proceedings were published via open access by the Internet Society. The calls for papers, programs, slides, and copies of the published papers are publicly available on the LASER website at https://www.laser-workshop.org/.

Starting in 2020, the LASER workshop model shifted from one of single annual workshops with solicited paper submissions, to one that co-locates with and proactively engages authors of accepted papers at major cybersecurity conferences. As noted above, the 2020 workshop was collocated with NDSS 2020. Another 2020 workshop was collocated with the Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC). Beyond 2020, the LASER workshop has been held twice a year in conjunction with both NDSS and ACSAC.

Under the new model, LASER proactively reaches out to and invites authors of accepted papers at NDSS and ACSAC to present the experimental aspects of their work at the workshop. Conference papers all too often focus on research results and contain limited discussion of the experimental aspects of the work (maybe a small section with a few paragraphs at the end of the paper). LASER provides authors the opportunity to come together as a group to explore and discuss the experimental aspects of their work. The workshop also invites open participation by other conference attendees interested in being part of and learning from such discussions. As a result of proactively reaching out to the conference paper authors, the LASER workshop has gained more participation from the cybersecurity community.

LASER is now offering a well-organized, established workshop with an important focus that complements major cybersecurity conferences. It is a good opportunity for authors of conference papers to present their work and potentially publish papers at LASER that focus on the experimental methodologies and lessons learned that supported the research results that formed the basis of their original papers. Since the workshop is collocating with NDSS and ACSAC, it is supported by the respective conferences and there are few expenses. Thus, there is good synergy between LASER and the major cybersecurity conferences and the LASER mission is being carried out by engaging the community in studying and learning from experimental methodologies utilized in cybersecurity research.
